content.description: Similar to Roundhouse, but not as aesthetic, with some sharp flakes.  Start on obvious flake, move up through a pocket, a pinch, and a weird flake undercling to a big right move to finish on Roundhouse.  Drop-off.

climbs.name: Stupid Human Tricks aka Whale's Belly

content.description: Start under the obvious overhang on a good sidepull. Move past another sidepull to a decent shallow pocket to the lip where a broken hold spot can be seen. Â Try to figure out the top out beta as this is where the meat of the climb begins. Definitely very hard. Downclimb on the low angle slab on the backside of the boulder.
content.location: Located on the Whale Boulder about 50 yards past the Roundhouse Boulder on the Rattlesnake Trail. Sit on the flat rock in the middle of the overhang and the start hold should be in your face. Climber's left of Beached Whale

content.description: Fun, steep climbing through flakes, sidepulls, and one pinch. It is common to just drop off the finish jug, since the topout is pretty rotten, and doesn't add much to the climb.
content.location: Center of three close-together lines on the Roundhouse boulder.

content.description: Obvious flake crack right of Roundhouse. Sit start and maneuver yourself up the flake finishing by matching the bomber jug over the top of the flake. The guidebook gives it v4, although an old guide to roped climbs at Coopers gave it 5.7! It's somewhere between the two, I think.
content.location: Rightmost line on the Roundhouse Boulder. This is on the massive obvious flake close to the center of the Boulder.

content.description: Sit-start on two small edges on the arete. Throw up to the lip then establish both hands on slopers and feet, start humping your way up the wall and figure out crazy mantle/beach whale/heel hook/whatever beta to top out on friction and no holds.
content.protection: couple pads for head protection for when you inevitably slip the first couple times.
content.location: Located on the Whale Boulder about 50 yards past the Roundhouse Boulder on the Rattlesnake Trail. It is the route closest to the trail on the arete.
